abstract.p: Letter from Paul C Berizzi (Environmental Action Coalition) supports prophylactic destruction of Norway maples to halt spread of Asian long-horned beetle (Aug 1 article); says the tree itself is a pest

Henry J. Stern, New York City's parks commissioner, has said prophylactic removal of host trees to slow the spread of the Asian long-horned beetle would involve ''killing tens of thousands of innocent trees'' (news article, Aug. 1). The principal host, and food source, for this beetle in New York City is the Norway maple, and how innocent is it?

The Norcross Wildlife Foundation says this tree's ''habits and growth rates are damaging our landscape.'' The Center for Conservation Biology at Stanford University suggests: ''Effective control of an invasive species must be to limit its spread. Eradication is a crucial first step.''
Killing Norway maples will exterminate a plant pest and may strike a serious blow against a destructive insect pest, too.
PAUL C. BERIZZI Executive Director Environmental Action Coalition New York, Aug. 2, 2000
